I put about a quarter inch of water in the pan and cook the bacon in that. The bacon cooks nicely at 100C/212F without burning while the water boils off. >didn't know the difference between corn oil and corn syrup. Didn't work out well. I may be retarded.
This category of mistake is pretty typical desu. Baking powder vs baking soda (luckily many recipes explicitly require both), curry leaves vs curry powder, there's probably hundreds of common confusions for novices. Even very experienced home cooks will always be out of a required ingredient from time to time and wonder, "Why can't I substitute X for Y?" and occasionally have a catastrophic failure. (This happened to my parents on a substitution for a recipe that they had made literally hundreds of times since they were children. Fwiw I'd rather have my parents be experimenting and failing occasionally than insisting on running to the grocery, which may require driving, every time there's a minute ingredient missing.)

It's impossible to recreate a good gyros seasoning. Same with döner. Imo the most important thing is to use a shit ton of herbs. Especially orgeano and thyme. MSG will also help.

"Hazelbank Fish Shop & Chinese Takeout"
It's rated 4 star on Google, but I wouldn't be surprised if that was entirely the owner doing his own SEO. It's not that it's bad, it's just not *that* good, but the fried noodles are better than the ones you'd get from yuppie restaurants in the area that give you half the serving size and somehow manage to fuck it up. This guy makes it like he's been making it his entire life, which he probably has. For $14.95 aud you get a full fucking wok of pretty amazing fried noodles, at the nearby RSL it's 20 bucks for a third of that.

The fish and chips there are absolutely garbage, and the deep fried stuff they serve gives me headaches (but that's typical for me and Chinese food, presumably due to an allergy to msg), but their fried rice and fried noodles? It's pretty good food and they give you a decently filled wok as a serving.

First, I slit your throat, drain all the blood into a basin and make congealed boiled blood.

The ribs, I will chop them into pieces, marinate them, then steam on top of some thinly sliced mountain yam. The legs are for curing. Fingers, toes and neck, to make gelatinous soup. >>18830501
You’re not heating it up enough. Put it on high heat and periodically a little water on it. When the droplets ball up and dances around like mercury, you know it is hot enough to add the oil.

The Leidenfrost Effect says that when the temperature of the pan gets hotter than the boiling point of water, as the water droplets hit the surface, the “bottom” of the droplet vaporizes so quickly that the vapor insulates the rest of the droplet and makes it float on the hot surface of the pan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18830719
Well, like that other anon said 'soap' was the wrong word. You use dishwasher detergent. But otherwise yeah, all you do is put in the detergent and turn the thing on. There's some things to keep in mind like not blocking the spinner sprayer with tall stuff if your unit has one, but otherwise it's literally just
>load dishes
>put in detergent
>power on
The pods are just detergent cakes or water soluble bags with pre-measured portions of detergent in them. I don't get them because they tend to be more expensive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I know that in moderation is a tired cliche but it still is generally true for an omnivore. We've got humans from across the dietary spectrum in history and I do not know of any severe difference in health/survival rate as long as you were getting the essential nutrition. I do know that in looking at mummies from Egypt, Meso/South America and the Arctic regions they found just about the same levels of heart disease despite the highly varied diet (and near exclusive meat consumption to the latter). Leading to a conclusion that heart disease is kind of just an inevitability of age.

https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2013/03/09/173918712/hardening-of-human-arteries-turns-out-to-be-a-very-old-story
>Well, the same research team did another study, broadening the the analysis to include mummies from three other preindustrial populations: 51 ancient Peruvians, five Ancestral Puebloans of the U.S. Southwest and five Unangan of Alaska's Aleutian Islands. They also included 76 more ancient Egyptians.
>Ultimately, calcium deposits signifying atherosclerosis were not hard to find across the four different cultures. More than a third of the 137 mummies showed signs of probable or definite hardened arteries, with 25 cases of calcification in the walls of preserved arteries and another 24 along the expected course of an artery.

I prefer beef but I will concede that pesco-vegetarianism with chicken/chicken products is likely the healthiest option. But the only reason to go vegan is pure emotionalism. And in terms of red meat the more smoked/processed shit is not as healthy for you but it's also not going to kill you if it's in moderation. You look at the nutrition of bacon and you'd have to eat a stupid amount to actually really be unhealthy.

>>18831101
From can: rinse gross bean juice in a sieve, * fry with some onion, garlic and spices like cumin, paprika, salt, oregano, chilli. Ready to go on your Mexican wraps or rice.
Raw/dry: soak for a few hours in fridge, drain water, add new water, boil until tender (google how long for whatever bean you have so you don't undercook), then continue from the above asterisk *

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18831101

soak the beans overnight with water and some baking soda to lower the acidity.
rinse the beans and put into pot, i use a slow cooker, cover with water, add:
salt, pepper, dry chilis, olive oil or lard, cumin seeds, coriander seeds, anise seeds, bouillon powder, diced onions, and minced garlic.
if its in a slow cooker, i set for 8 hours and leave it alone.
if its in a pot, i get it to a simmer, cover and leave for at least 4 hours checking on the water level and testing the beans for doneness.

when the beans are cooked i remove the chili pods, add a bit of white vinegar to the cooked beans and liquid to raise the acidity so that they keep longer, strain the beans into a container and cover with the remaining liquid.

>>18831101
OP, since it hasn't been mentioned, lets talk about bean quality.

Like any ingredient, beans will vary in quality. Higher quality beans will hold together better when cooking, taste better, and have a better texture; all around pleasant and easier to cook. Not only does the quality matter, but beans do have a shelf-life as well. While it takes many years for beans to become inedible, after 1-2 years the beans will begin to degrade and split, becoming more difficult to cook properly. It's not uncommon when receiving expired beans for whatever reason, either from a unscrupulous supplier or in a charity parcel, that the bean will never be cooked in an ideal way, you may never get thoroughly-cooked whole beans, and the best way to consume at this point is some short of puree, like refried beans, bean dip, or hummus.

A good way to tell if you've got old beans, if you see any that are split in half. Also avoid any beans that look wrinkled, or have broken skins.

posts.com: I still dont understand what defines a good knife

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18831602
A lot of different things. Starting with a handle which is secure, grippable, but does not tire the hand with prolonged use. Then you need a blade that is rigid without being overheavy or too thick, bearing an acute edge that is sharp and durable without being axelike and inefficient. The length should be sufficient for the task without engendering drag or being unwieldy. Finally, the tip should have a form commensurate with use, being neither dangerous nor obstructive to the task. The material of the blade should be hard enough to bear work but soft enough to resist shattering force and to allow resharpening.

These are the fundamentals, and even they may shift with the purpose of the knife.

>>18831290

The best thing you can do is to walk into a store that sells knives and try holding them in your hands.

A knife you don't feel comfortable with will in hand will not be a knife you will be confident in using, and will just end up collecting rust in a drawer.

There's a good reason why Zwelling has such gigantic market share; they push hard to have their entire range on display at 3rd party retailers, and double down by setting up physical retail locations with their entire catalogue on display, including their super premium Kramers.

Because at the end of the day, at a similar price point, any normal person in the market for high end knives would rather purchase a Zwilling or Myabi they can physically hold in their hands over a Wustof or Shun they can only see online.

>>18821662
This is probably the best option for them, but they likely won't go for it. I don't know if I'd be able to convince them to drop $100 for a used grinder. I may just buy it for them and hope they'll use it.

My parents' coffee situation is weird and, I think, a little bit funny. When I was growing up, they would drink shitty pre-ground Yuban or whatever they'd buy in bulk at Costco. About fifteen years ago, I got a part time at Starbucks, and got them a free bag of a coffee they sell called Casi Cielo, a seasonal Guatemalan coffee they sell, and probably the best whole bean coffee Starbucks carries. They fell in love with it, and asked me to hoard my free bags of coffee and ship it to them, instead of flipping it on eBay as I usually did. I haven't worked at Starbucks in about a decade, but my dad will still go to the local stores and buy up their entire supply whenever it's available, and now it's all they drink and told me they can't really stand the shitty pre-ground supermarket stuff. If they run out of that coffee, they'll switch to tea. When I visited them yesterday, I offered to grind their coffee with my hand grinder, but my mom stopped me because she immediately knew it would make a huge difference to have fresh burr-ground coffee, and she sort of didn't want to know, because she knew the financial rabbit hole coffee snobbery can lead to. They're reluctant to try better beans or better grinders, or better brew methods because they don't want to "have to" start spending more money on their morning coffee.

>>18821970
They burn your coffee, no matter what kind you use.
>they minimise the heated contact of the boiler to just boil the liquid right below the tube
They heat up the whole thing. Just because you pinpoint heat a bit of the plate that doesn't mean that heat isn't going to be distributed throughout all the liquid. You'd need to isolate the liquid you're heating if you wanted to even attempt this, and you fundamentally can't because you need more liquid to pour in.
And I'm using the word liquid instead of water because the brewed coffee just falls back into the sea of water, gets burned and circulates again and again. It's a horrible brewing method. If you're this lazy just us a mr. coffee or equivalent.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823549
A faster, more even extraction is still preferable to a slower uneven one. Its not all that coarse of a grind fwiw, you're just used to looking at massive amounts of fines all over the bed. Better grinders(the anon above is either using a zp6 or kafatek flat) with more narrow particle distributions will let you get away with coarser grinds, but tastier cups because you're more evenly extracting the coffee.
>This shows exactly the “common knowledge” curve I was talking about earlier; if you grind too fine, average extraction yield goes down because your extraction becomes more uneven.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2020/04/02/why-cant-we-grind-coffee-finer-for-pour-over/
>Whenever too many coffee fines get trapped in the pores of a paper filter, the drip rate of a coffee brew can go down drastically. This is not only a problem because the brew becomes much longer: the bigger issue is that whatever water is still able to pass through will do so along smaller, and unchanging paths through the filter. This means that large regions of the coffee bed will potentially stop receiving fresh water, and will remain under extracted, while other regions will receive the bulk of the flow and contribute astringency or other unpleasant flavors caused by over extraction.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2021/03/04/the-four-rules-of-optimal-coffee-percolation/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18830349
grind a bit coarser than espresso
fill the basket
level it out with a knife or something
dont tamp it or press it down
boil water
pour boiling water in base
put full basket in base
screw top on bas
put moka on the smallest burner(if you dont have gas i dont consider you a human)
put the heat to max, the flame ring should be the same diameter as the base of the moka
wait until coffee starts to flow
as soon as you cant see the silver bottom of the top half of the moka turn the heat to min
wait until the coffee reaches halfway to the bottom of the spout(you will have to eyeball this)
at this point turn the heat off
once the coffee has reached the bottom of the spout take it off the stove and run the base under cold water for 15-25 seconds making sure not to spill coffee
pour coffee and enjoy

its that simple.
also you may be getting grit because you are using a standard filter which sucks, try buying a E&B Lab competition filter. it is easily the best moka filter you can buy and it costs less than $20(im pretty sure.)

you can also put an aeropress filter on the moka filter(wet it a bit to make sure it sticks), this will make sure no fines or grit end up in the cup (and will slightly increase back pressure) but it will remove alot of the natural oils of the coffee and affect the taste and mouthfeel.
i hope this helps.
this is my method that i took from hoffmann and wired gourmet and have been using it 2-3 times every day for a year and it works perfectly every time.
if you follow this and still have problems then thats on you.

>>18830466
you are 100% wrong.
when making broth with bones you will get a layer of scum that forms on top of the broth after cooking for a while. to make a good broth you need to skim off this scum and throw it out.
that last 5-10% of potential liquid that sputters is the scum of the moka.
it tastes bad and will objectively taint the taste of the rest of the moka.
is it really worth it to go from 160g of tasty well made coffee to 190g bitter over extracted badly made coffee?
if it is then fine be content with being someone who enjoys drinking a large amount of bad coffee.
but if you had any intelligence at all you would say no i dont want that.

Did you try this place?
https://www.manucafe.cz/
I buy from them for about 2 years. I'm very happy with them,fast,very good package. A very big variety. When they have something special they give a notice. I grind manual, my dad his old coffee grinder. He used it till he died,still does a great job. He used the paper filter . Last few years I use only the French press, you can control the brew better, all depending what you are in the mood for. Short,long, etc. A lot of experimenting .
When I'm in a hurry it's the machine who grinds and makes the coffee.
For the first time I watched videos of people making coffee, the links given here.
There is some method in it to make a good coffee, but, everyone has different taste. My coffee is made different a lot of times, depending how I feel or what I'm in the mood for. All those videos look like a copy of one, all copying the other one pretending to be the expert, social media copycat give me likes .
Everyone tastes it differently, I have a friend who loves his coffee beyond believe, I'm like wtf when I taste it.
Then I have an aunt who say Starbucks has the best coffee ever. So I drove 90 kilometers to praha to taste it, you hear so much that name ,so let's try it. I sipped on it and left it there. Who wants to pay that money for that stuff.
We all see different, hear different, smell different and taste different. If you like your brew ,be happy.
People learn something new every day, it's good to improve.
Coffee is good. The hardest drug I ever had, never been able to quit, no matter how hard I tried after doctors request.
My max without was 2 weeks, when family visited during weekend having coffee, the smell,... I wanted to snort coffee ground on the toilet seat in a blacked out bathroom.
Don't forget that link, so many beans, so many countries, so many flavors .
Coffee.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820505
Hotdog stands in denmark, they are unlike any other hotdogs and it's so difficult to place, I've tried so many dog types and sausages but they're not the same. they also have pickled cucumbers that aren't like regular pickles. there was this remolade yellow sauce that tasted like a really refined big mac sauce. I ate so many of them when I visited and they had stands literally everywhere. It's almost scary how common they are. Stayed a couple nights on the coast in a really rural part. it had like one store for groceries within 20 miles and no other commerce aside from farms. Even in that remote old people place there was still a god damn hot dog trailer that would park outside the grocery every day. I swear you could go hiking in the forest, go off the beaten trail, fall into a ravine and find a hotdog stand at the bottom of it. Only visited once though, so maybe I just had crazy luck.
it's unique because I've never called a hotdog "refreshing" but that's the best way I could describe it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18832725
This is the whole reason stock was made the way it used to be. So you could make a separate sauce.
You need to do a two stage process building up flavour. You start with making your stock how you likely normally do with browned bones. Then you brown some meat and mirepoix. Degrease it. Then pour some of the first stage liquid in just to almost cover the meat.and reduce it to a glaze. Repeat this multiple times then add all the stock and simmer until the meat has no more flavour left. Strain, and that is your stock.

posts.com:
We'll be making kkakdugi today. Picrel, our ingredients:
>daikon radish (well, at least a type of radish that is closest to it and available here)
>Korean chili flakes (gochugaru)
>onio
>scallion
>fish sauce
>salt
>honey

Few things. Yes, I made this before, 4 times, in fact. I know that there's an online debate going on whether honey is an appropriate substitute for sugar. (Honey has anti-bacterial properties, making people think it will stop kimchi from fermenting. It does not. I'm speaking from experience.) Moving on, and regarding gochugaru, I came to the conclusion that it is an ingredient that is absolutely superior to all the alternatives, and I admit this in shame, since I'm from a culture that prouds itself for its paprika/chili obsession (Hungary).

About my choice of different types of onions: scallion &... "regular" onions. I just like the difference in texture, basically. And lastly, about the quality of my salt... I admit, it's substandard. Koreans emphasize that it should be the coarsest salt you can get - mine is not. Apoligies.

If you join this thread: progrock posting is welcome as thread bumps.

I know what you mean OP. A good method for this is to skip the mornay altogether and just boil your pasta in milk. Pour in just enough milk to submerge the macaroni, bring to a simmer slowly (slowly is important so the milk doesn't burn or split), take off the heat when cooked and dump in the cheese. It's perfect since you can adjust the consistency to your liking with no guess work by adding more cheese for cheesier or stirring in some milk/cream for creamier. The pasta's starch will be adequate to bind and thicken the sauce without the need for flour. Saves on dishes. I make mac like this every time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't like roux-based macaroni and cheese for the same reason, OP.

As stated elsewhere in this thread, using a different emulsifier like sodium citrate will retain more cheese flavor. Using sodium citrate I was able to make a sauce that was... far too cheesy.

Sodium citrate is a specialty ingredient that you would likely have to order and have shipped. You can add american cheese which contains similar emulsifiers, if you don't mind tainting your sauce with american cheese (personally I do mind).

Another option is to use small amounts of lemon juice and baking soda. The citric acid in lemon juice reacts with the baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) off-gassing carbon dioxide and creating citric acid salts, AKA sodium citrate. This does not make your sauce taste lemony, since the tartness of the lemon juice is neutralized in the reaction.

I've used this method professionally to created 100,000s of portions of macaroni and cheese.

>>18830377

Drink a tablespoon of apple cider vinegar mixed into in a cup of warm water first thing in the morning. Doesn't taste or smell great, but if you can get it down, it did help me some.

As far as what to eat; trying drinking more water throughout the day. Avoid having caffeine, chocolate, or artificial sweeteners like aspartame multiple times a day. Try alkali foods like green beans every meal.

Drinking hot water with lemon wedge squeezed and mixed into it every night after I'm done eating for the day helped me too. I know the lemon is acidic but somehow it worked for me; I think it helps flush your gut or something.

Wait at least 2 hours after eating before lying flat.

If you're having pain at night, try propping yourself up and sleeping. Pepcid and tylenol can help manage that pain but really shouldn't be a treatment to use regularly. Neither should PPI's unless you really need them, because they can form a dependency.

Certain medications including OTC ones like minoxidil can relax the pyloric sphincter and thus cause release of excess stomach acid.

>>18830361
Depends on why you actually have "acid reflux" or GERD.

Hate to be the bearer of bad news, but all the people coming out of the woodwork with "wheat gluten" intolerances, or "milk casein" intolerances thought they simply had simply had acid reflux too.

Turns out there is a minor auto immune disorder that was only discovered in like 2010.
It makes your throat BURN just like you have acid reflux, but in reality its your throat having a minor allergic reaction attacking itself.

If you take pepto bismol or you take TUMS and the acid reflux doesnt go away, there is a good chance you have it.

Its extremely prevalent, and its just randomly showing up in people in their late 20s early 30s.
Turns out they think Triclosan long term exposure in toothpaste and soaps at a young age is one of the major causes. Turns out they pumped it into everything like 25 years ago and only just stopped recently.

Apparently its always been around and people just have said "Oh its just GERD" so it went under the radar for so long.

Go to your doctor and ask to get a blood titer test for allergens and see what they say.

>>18830617
Eosinophilic esophagitis.

The cause is reaction to wheat and sugar. The symptoms listed on places like Mayo clinic make this sound like something you can just "get" that popped into existence in the 90s for unknown reasons. You're correct to link the self-diagnosed gluten intolerance to this disorder. Unfortunately, simply cutting wheat from the diet doesn't fix it for most people if they also drink alcohol and eat a lot of sugar. The body is doing everything in its power to reject what we are eating because it's complete trash.
The publicly available line about a "genetic component" to eosinophilic esophagitis because "it tends to run in families" is nonsense and unscientific gibberish. Families are structured according to their economic class in this era, not just birth lineage. In reality, those who work the hardest and longest for wages have the problem the greatest. It's less common to see this in rich people. Despite being a class based disease (like many diseases), there are a few steps some people can take, which involves the reduction in the following consumption:
• Breads/wheat + noodles
• Sugar, including table sugar not just HFCS, not including artificial sweeteners
• Alcohol. It's processed in the body very similarly to the above.
• Fruit, it doesn't matter where the sugar comes from. It's still causing reaction before steps are taken
• Potatoes to a lesser degree
• Corn
This is a necessary component since at the end of the day this is autoimmune. There's no getting around that, at least at first.
After a couple of months, your relationship to food has changed and so your body follows. This is why those who have been on a Ketogenic diet have been uplifted out of this miserable disorder—their relationship to food changed away from what the food monopolies have made the norm. It's not because of ketosis itself for this disorder.
Also add the following to speed up the process:
• Fiber (celery, etc)
• Fats (butter, lard, etc)

posts.name: Anonymous

Cont.
Once healthy, a slow re-introduction of a couple of these foods in low quantities/frequencies is fine. If you get disphagia/burning again, cut again and start over. It means the old relationship is back and the body has fallen into reaction. This is a socially caused disorder after all, not one made from individual choice. So you should expect to roll back down that hill a little. But if you do, you'll have a better understanding of how to change the relationship and for how long. If you're desperate, you could jump right into low carb or keto like some people have done, but that's not possible for everyone. Hope this helps someone.

>>18832609
Baking soda, also known as sodium bicarbonate, can help neutralize stomach acid and alleviate symptoms of acid reflux. The recommended dosage is 1/2 teaspoon to 2 teaspoons in a glass of water, taken after meals or when acid reflux symptoms occur. However, it's important to note that baking soda is high in sodium, so it should be used with caution and only under the guidance of a healthcare provider, especially if you have high blood pressure or other conditions that affect your sodium levels. Additionally, it is not recommended to use it for an extended period of time. If you have frequent acid reflux or heartburn, please see your doctor.

posts.com:
Spicy food does not cause acid reflux. Acidic food does not either. But if your stomach refluxes, back up into your esophagus, the presence of this stuff is going to make the burn worse. Part of the effect but not the cause.

Stomach acid is used to break down carbs. (Similarly, bile is used for fat.) The more carbs (sugars, starches) you eat, the more stomach acid production.

If you eat lots of carbs and sleep shortly after, and are prone to laying level or with your head lower than your body, even a hair, you're going to get reflux. Simple gravity. Being overweight adds to the effect although I don't know why.

I used to live on pasta and this crap started happening to me, 2011-12. I cut out all the carbs and it went away. Hasn't been a problem since.

Listen here, I am the only guy you should listen to in this thread. Why? Because I've had acid reflux since I was 16 and I'm 30 now. It comes and goes for me still, but here are some major factors:
1) Smoking cigarettes. If you smoke cigarettes, you're gonna have acid reflux no matter what you do with the other tips here.
2) Eating too close to sleep time. Try and finish your last bite at least 2.5 hours before you sleep.
3) Soda/coffee/beer. IDK what it is, but these three cause me insane amounts of acid reflux. Avoid/reduce your consumption of these.
4) Overeating. You can continue to eat the same amount of food per day, but just split it into more meals.
5) Fibre. This one helped me the most. Eating lots of leafy greens and veggies really helped me have less acid reflux.

>>18827079
>The name Champagne on a Cognac bottle refers to its origin, namely the growth area the grapes were grown in. There are six growth areas–or “terroirs”–in total, and the two that are considered to produce the finest eau-de-vie are named Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. These two premium terroirs have soil that compares to the soil of the Champagne region in Northern France. Hence the shared name.

>A Cognac is called a “Fine Champagne Cognac” when it contains a blend of eaux-de-vie from both Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. At least 50% of the blend have to be from the Grande Champagne. When the word Champagne is used on a Cognac, it will either be preceded by the word, Grande, Petite, or Fine. This simply denotes the terroir in which the grapes were grown.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829472
I typically use a chefs knife; I score a line where I need the cap to separate from the bottle by gently running the blade around the circumference where the bottom of the bottle cap meets the glass, then I use the back of the knife to crack the wax. Don’t worry about damaging the cork, the cork itself is attached to a plastic cap and there’s no need to remove the wax from the cap. See picrel, that’s my 1982 Delord. I’m pretty OCD so I gun for a clean cut as pictured since I like my bottles looking nice. This takes experience though. The first time you do it you’re gonna be messy, so do it on a big empty table or kitchen top where you’ve got plenty of space so you can subsequently wipe all the chipped pieces of wax off with ease. Enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829472
Oh and re: the ABV, it’s honestly fine. Most Armagnac is ABV’d @ 40% (you can get higher), and I’ve had some pretty solid whisky at 40% even though I generally lean a wee bit higher for my favourites. I just had my Delord with my partner and we both agree no cheese or mushroom in the nose, palate and finish, lol. Looking at my tasting notes though, this is what I wrote: nose: extremely grape-y, like sniffing a well packed bouquet of fruits and berries packed in a basket held together by UHU glue; palate: sweet, minty and clinical, hard to pinpoint individual flavours, there’s something synthetic about the flavour but in a way I very much enjoy, it just tastes super clean; finish: the synthetic part really comes out here, plasticky but damn it’s addictive (bits of the UHU glue nose come out here on your taste buds, and just like UHU glue, it’s god damn addictive). This definitely won’t be everyone’s cup of tea, but god damn am I always in a heightened state of zen whenever I take my shot from this bottle.

>>18829703
lol yeah. Laubade does that, there’s a cloth string a few mm wide under the wax which you can just pull to get the fucker off. The problem with Delord isn’t the lack of string though, it’s that the wax is like fucking porcelain i.e. really hard. My older bottles of Laubade had no string but even despite that the wax was super easy to peel off. I typically don’t ever leave a bottle open for more than three months so I don’t have an issue with ageing becoming a problem. I typically drink one shot a day with my significant other (we do have one or two breaks a week though), sometimes we share one shot, sometimes we have a shot each; so with my rule of four open bottles at once that pretty much guarantees each bottle will finished within three months. I devised this rule mostly because for whisky it can be very unpredictable how well a bottle ages, and in my experience it’s not uncommon for shit to go downhill fast once the bottle is about 50% empty with all that air mucking about inside. Funnily enough I find Armagnac holds much better than whisky; I once had a bottle open for over a year and I still thoroughly enjoyed it. But like my current Glenfiddich 15 VAT 03 that’s open, I can tell I’m enjoying it a wee bit less now that the bottle is down to its remainder 35%. Still solid, but not quite as phenomenal as when the cap first came off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18833006
Kek. In my shithole (Singapore) alcohol is taxed at a fixed value per litre or alcohol, not percentage. The sheer irony is that this basically means our alcohol tax is a poor people’s tax more than anything because for cheaper shit you pay a higher percentage in tax (since the product is cheaper but the tax is fixed): thus the more expensive your liquor the more meaningless the tax becomes (you pay the same $ per litre regardless of whether you’re buying a 20$ piss wine or a 1000$ or fuck it 10000$ bottle of scotch). Beer is thus pretty damn costly here (we’re one of the most expensive countries to buy beer in), but once you go into the 3-figure range like I dunno a Dewar’s 32, it’s often cheaper here than in Europe.

Try blanched green beans in salted water. Pull one out when they turn bright green and taste test. Quench them in cold water or ice water before they turn soft. They are delicious cold and you will end up eating a handful of them every time you open the fridge. But you can try to keep enough around for sautéing or stir frying.

Cabbage and bacon, shredded cabbage sautéed in butter, coleslaw, sauerkraut–there are too many delicious things to do with cabbage to list. The rabbit hole goes deep.

Yes, brussels sprouts are incredible. On simple days I like to cut in half and pan fry them flat side down in butter, then add salt and black pepper, but you can use any fat. Or roast them in any combo of bacon fat, olive oil, butter, etc. Salt, pepper, garlic or anything. Go all out with a balsamic reduction finish.

Creamed spinach is also excellent (frozen works great). Sautéed or grilled mushrooms, yellow squash/zucchini are nice. Choose the vegetables in season. You'll know by the low prices.

>>18829225
Broccoli is practically a superfood. If you're eating it once a week in stir fries you're fine. More than that you're fine. Don't listen to retarded articles on buzzfeed.

Vegetables basically take on the flavor of whatever you cook them with. Pick something new and find a recipe with it, or use them as a side. Most vegetables are simple and require simple preparation. Some basic suggestions:
Mushrooms - fry them in butter and garlic, or get some portobellos (the big ones) and stuff them with things you like and bake. Toss in dried shiitake to your ramen of choice + bok choy for easy upgrade.
Root vegetables for roasting/baking - add any mix of your favorite seasonings i.e cumin, chili flakes, s/p, rosemary/thyme and roast till cooked/crispy.
Lentil/beans can easily replace beef in certain recipes/cuisines. Canned for ease of use. Learn how to make chili.
Greens can be steamed and drizzled with olive oil, lemon juice and s/p. Or soy sauce, sesame oil/seeds if asian inspired. Kewpie sesame mayo is a godsend. Just throw in any leafy greens to whatever you're cooking for lazy vitamins.

posts.com:
>>18829113
So vegetables smelling like farts is a product of dumb housewives and cafeteria cooks overcooking things, specifically brassica family plants; cabbage, broccoli, brussel sprouts, kohlrabi.

Anyway, one of my favorites for brussel sprouts. Super simple and damn good.
1. Get ~1 lb brussel sprouts, remove any discolored leaves, wash and dry, then split in half.
2. Put halved sprouts in a large bowel, add about a tablespoon of salt and toss well. You want these suckers to be evenly salted.
3. Drizzle in a tablespoon or two of olive oil, a clove or two of minced or crushed garlic, and a two teaspoons of a chopped herb of your choosing. Choose something strong, mind, sprouts stand up well to big flavors. I like rosemary.
4. Mix together extremely well and evenly as best you can.
5. Heat oven to 450 F and let your sprouts soak in the salt, oil, and flavorings. Ideally the sprouts have 30-40 minutes to get good and tasty, but work with what time you have.
6. Once the ovens' hot, put the sprouts on a rimmed baking sheet and bake for 10 minutes. Remove from oven, stir and flip and shit, put back in and bake again for 15 minutes.
7. Take 'em out early if they're starting to burn though, ovens are weird. They're done when a fork goes through with little resistance, and smaller leaves are dark and brittle like kale chips.
8. Let them cool for a bit these bastards are hot! But enjoy once you can eat them without burning your mouth.

>>18833367
I actually found that the key to a good french omelette or any omelette that you intend to roll and look neat and smooth is to use less fat in the cooking stage. The fat causes the egg curds to separate more easily, and less fat means the eggs will be more cohesive, smooth, and stuck to each other more. Butter can be added in the rolling stage so you have melted butter between the layers, or simply add melted butter on top of the finished omelette on the plate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My prefered way of cooking eggs is separating the yolks from the white. Cooking the whites completely either like an egg white omelette or just egg white scramble, and some light browning on whites is pretty good.

And with the yolks you can make a hollandaise sauce with lottsa butter.

you serve by putting the cooked egg whites on top of some toasted bread followed by pouring the hollandaise on top. Or make it into a sandwich and have the hollandaise in the sandwich or on the side to dip your sandwich into.

Of course you can supplement this whole recipe with bacon bits, onions, or other veggies or meat of your choice.

It's a lot of work separating the eggs and making hollandaise sauce but the end result is worth it if you have the time and the will.

Heinz ketchup is a well-established brand with a long history and a strong reputation. Other brands can compete against Heinz by differentiating themselves in various ways:

Quality: Other brands can focus on producing a higher-quality product that stands out in terms of taste, texture, or ingredients.

Innovation: Brands can create new and unique flavors or formulations that set them apart from Heinz.

Marketing: Brands can create a strong brand identity and marketing campaign that highlights their unique selling points and resonates with consumers.

Distribution: Brands can focus on expanding their distribution channels and building relationships with retailers to increase their visibility and accessibility to consumers.

Price: Brands can target price-sensitive consumers by offering their products at a lower price point than Heinz.

Social responsibility: Brands can communicate their commitment to sustainability, fair trade, or other ethical practices to appeal to consumers who prioritize these values.

Ultimately, the key to competing against Heinz is to understand the preferences and needs of the target consumers and to offer a product that meets those needs in a unique and compelling way.

>>18831656
The Yukon isn't that mysterious.
White people have been here for like 150 years and there are tons of resource roads, rivers and trails you can use to access the backcountry.
Also there's loads of young white people from Toronto who come up here for a few years to work for government and ruin our housing market.
Still, one of the last places with actual wilderness. I did a 4 day paddle around one of the southern lakes two years ago and the only other people I saw were an older couple living in an off grid cabin on the lake. Didn't even see another boat in four days of paddling.
If I was so inclined I could walk into the woods behind my house and hike for 200+ km in a straight line without encountering a road or trail.

posts.com:
>>18832319
Bardzimi is just the brand, although I've never heard of that particular brand before. The drink itself is called тapхyн (tarkhun), which is literally just the Russian word for tarragon. It was created in Georgia about 100 years ago but now it's popular throughout the former Soviet countries. If you're curious it's relatively easy to make at home using sugar, soda water and fresh tarragon leaves which should be in your local supermarket.

It has absolutely nothing to do with alcohol, it's just an ordinary soda, although I have seen people using it as a chaser for vodka.

>>18826611
Although that sounds nice and it's a meme, it's still a meme.

Try this: A bag of rice, chicken stock bouillon cubes (I like Knorr), oil (I like olive oil, I believe the seed oil meme), and multiple hot sauces.

>Take a pot
>Put in oil
>Heat it up
>Put rice in
>stir
>Toast rice until it starts to brown a little, NOT black
>Add water
>Add bouillon cube
>When it starts to boil turn it down
>Turn off after about 15 or so minutes depends on rice and amount
>let it sit for a few minutes
>perfect rice
Toasting rice means you don't have to wash it, or at least that's what I've learned.
The sauces will allow you to get a different flavor each time. I recommend A1 Steak sauce, green tabasco sauce, and sriracha to start off with..

If you want to get fancy, add half an onion as you're toasting, before adding rice to let it get cooked more, and then add pic related, its only like $0.50. That's how you can make an easy mexican rice.

posts.com:
Been to prison so this is my expertise.

Obviously this can be done with real versions of all of these ingredients, but lacks the sovl of the prison goyslop

Choose spicy or non spicy variants
6 packs ramen of your choosing
1 container Velveeta jalapeno cheese spread. Mix with milk in bowl and stir until creamy liquid consistency.
1 pouch hot chili with beans
1 spicy beef summer sausage. Chop into small cubes using your prison ID card. Lay flat and microwave until it sizzles
Smash ramen packs up so noodles are very broken. Cook noodles in low temp hot water so the noodles expand and are very soft
Microwave chili, heat cheese
Drain water, add seasoning packets
Mix everything together very thoroughly. Save some cheese
Jalapeno slices to taste
pickle eaters consider diced pickles as the defining feature but I don't eat them

Top with chips of your choice. Best imo for this are hot fritos. They don't really get soggy and have the best crunch.
Followed up by prison or ghetto only obtainable flavored chips: Buffalo wing and blue cheese, and the whole shabang.
Drizzle rest of the cheese over top

I use chili ramen
Bonus points if you could sneak some diced onion from the chow hall

This serving size is usually the contribution of 3 people pitching in 1/3 of the ingredients, and teaming up on the prep. This makes 3 massive portions that depending on the person will eat right when made, and have something for late night snack. Or mostly beggers will come out and ask for some, and you'll be so fucking full you'll share the wealth as others hopefully do for you if you aren't a dumb cuck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
heres a recipe I made for a friend for my lasagna.

I never used a written recipe and learned from watching someone else make it. They never used a written recipe either.

all amounts were pulled out of my ass based on a best guess for the recipe. because the amounts of many of the seasonings don't matter that much. The person I gave it to said it was the best lasagna they had ever had. they had no trouble making it and never questioned me on exact measurements.

2 lbs. sweet and/or hot Italian sausage
1 package Lasagna Noodles
1 Table spoon olive oil
2 16oz. cans diced or crushed stewed tomatoes
2 or 3 lbs. Mozzarella cheese
Italian seasoning
dried chopped parsley
2 or 3 pints ricotta cheese
2 or 3 eggs
1 white onion medium to large
6 to 8 medium size mushrooms
2 or 3 cloves fresh garlic

Mix the 2 or 3 eggs, 2 or 3 tablespoons parsley, and Ricotta cheese together.

Chop the Mushrooms.

Boil the noodles in a large saucepan with the oil, and 1 tsp. salt in the water,
cook until still tough. drain and refill pan with cold water to keep noodles from
sticking together.

Coarse chop the onion, smash and finely dice 1 or 2 cloves of garlic.
Remove the sausage casing, and break up the sausage in a frying pan.
Brown the sausage with 2/3 the onion and all the garlic, salt and pepper to taste.
Drain off the grease.

In a 2 quart sauce pan combine the Stewed tomatoes, 1 tsp. Italian seasoning, the rest of the onion, 1 crushed and finely chopped clove of garlic, the mushrooms, and the Sausage.
bring to boil and then simmer about 15 minutes.

Arrange in layers in a ungreased 9x13" pan: sauce, ricotta cheese, mozzarella, and pasta.
Top the last layer with a generous amount of mozzarella.
Bake at 350 for 20 to 25 minutes or until sauce bubbles and the cheese is slightly brown.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Coming soon are Shiitake which appear to colonize very slow, and King Trumpet which appears to colonize very fast.

On the top shelf are some hens of the woods which I just bagged. For them I'm trying a different technique than normal. I just used straight unsupplemented sawdust (rather than sawdust + soy hulls) for a few reasons. Firstly, mixing the sawdust and soy pellets is annoying and takes a long time to get an even mixture. Secondly, sterilizing them takes forever and is annoying, but with straight sawdust it's not necessary to sterilize because it's not nutritious enough for mold (I hope). And then, it's also annoying to put the grains inside the bags inside my SAB after sterilization and then shake them up. In all my previous attempts, I haven't gotten a good mix and the mycelium just starts on top and has to grow down to colonize the rest of the sawdust which takes a long time. For these, I just hydrated the sawdust pellets in a bucket, and then mixed the grains into the mix, and then put the mixture right into the bags. It saved a ton of work and I think it will colonize faster because it's much more evenly mixed. So if it doesn't contam then I will probably not bother with the soy hulls anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18831356
I've done a few batches of "creative" mushrooms in my life, and I got all my information by browsing shroomery. Sorry but I don't have a link to a specific guide. When I decided to do these oysters I just did a quick Google about what they should eat and most of the theory pretty much carries over.

If you're worried about contamination just imagine that the air and every object in your home is covered in germs unless it's been pressure cooked or flame-sterilized. Don't expose anything to the open air except in a still air box, and don't let anything touch your materials except flame-sterilized implements. Be vigilant about this and you'll be fine. The only things that can be exposed to open air and unsanitary objects are fully colonized grains (as the mycelium's immune system protects it) and non-nutritive substrates like coir or straw.

The only expensive piece of equipment you need is a pressure canner but it'll pay for itself quickly. Plus you can use it to make jars of food last forever, or to pressure cook a whole turkey. I have this one which isn't even that expensive: https://www.walmart.com/ip/Presto-16-Quart-Pressure-Canner-and-Cooker-01745/5913467?athbdg=L1101

Do you live near a store that sells those mushrooms? They sell lions mane in most wholefoods. You'll save time and money by buying a fresh one and cloning it. Growing from spore takes a lot longer.

>>18832476
>>18832487
If OP has dagnosed celiac, then that's that. There's a test, and it's final, and then the doctors put you on the diet. Then people started making gluten-free into a fad diet (along the same evolution of Atkins and other low-to-no-carb diets) and were claiming "Non-Celiac Gluten Sensitivity" or NCGS, which is a controversial phenomenon at best in the medical literature.

It's similar with keto, which is a legit diet that existed for decades as a treatment-of-last-resort for severe treatment-resistant epileptics (we're talking one step prior to cutting their brain in half here). Then, in the same line of genesis of low-carb diets from Atkins, it became reimagined for the general public as a fad diet, even though it has absolutely fuck all to do for the general population what its original intent was.

Arguably these medically-inspired fad diets have been a net good thing for society, as they have raised at least some bare minimal awareness for horrible diseases and the requirements some people need in daily life to live through them, and have made such requirements easier for those people to meet. And while the counterargument to that is that people cite gluten-free and keto pseudoscience to be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes, I'd argue that those people would be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes anyway. (The internet in general probably makes it worse, though).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
20-30 crayfish
½ bunch of dill
1 lemon
1 tbsp. salt
½ tbsp. sugar
1 dl beer
water to cover the crayfish
COURSE OF ACTION
Put water in a saucepan and add dill, salt, sugar and lemon zest. Let it boil for 10 minutes. Bring on the beer.
Wash the crayfish and prepare them.
Then put your crayfish in the pan with the boiling water. Bring them to the boil quickly and let them boil for 1 minute. Remove the pan from the heat and leave them to cool.
Now serve the freshly cooked crayfish on a plate, preferably with toasted bread, mayonnaise and dill on the side.

posts.com:
So I've had people rant and rave at me for ages about how amazing rice cookers are
Me, I'm just a regular idiot who cooks rice on a stovetop. The directions say, equal parts water, cook 15 minutes, don't take the lid off. So that's what I do and the rice is cooked and perfect in 15 minutes.

Then I got a rice cooker for christmas, I'd always wanted one, I was pretty excited.

And you know what? It's fucking crap. It cooks rice fine but what takes me 15 minutes on a stovetop takes 50!!! minutes in a rice cooker. The rice that comes out is otherwise identical, and the rice cooker takes like 3 minutes longer to clean than my pot does. because it's got more parts. I've clearly missed something here because this is not easier and more convenient for rice cooking, it takes the exact same amount of effort as cooking on stovetop but 4x longer to cook and a little more effort to clean.

So why the hell do people buy these things instead of just cooking on the stove? Is it really so fucking hard to just not lift the lid to stir the rice for 99% of the population or something???

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813813
It depends on the type of rice down to the specific cultivar really, but great rice is when you coax the most flavor and desirable texture out of your rice.

If you cook rice exactly the same every time you are not good at cooking rice. As rice ages, and the variance from bag to bag it needs adjustment in the cooking process, mainly more or less water.

If you aren't critically assessing the rice you mads, and thinking of how you can try to improve it the majority of the time you aren't even on the path of achieving great rice. You're merely using it as an easy filler food.

Rice is easy to cook, difficult to perfect.

Rice cookers are convenient because they hold the rice at a warm temperature after they are done and you literally can't fuck it up unless you mismeasure. It's one task that no longer requires your attention at all(whereas stovetop rice requires you to at least be minimally aware and can be burnt). Many people are very anxious in the kitchen, so they overvalue the idiot-proof nature of the rice cooker.

That being said, if you eat rice every day they are great. A good rice cooker can not only cook perfect rice without effort, it can also hot hold it all day, and reheat leftover rice perfectly.

Personally, I mostly eat Basmati rice at home, so I just boil it like pasta if I want plain rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813853
>>18814657
No, the previous anon is 100% correct. I cook over 90 litres of sushi rice a week and the amount of water required to get the correct consistency varies from an even 1/1 ratio to 1/1.25 depending on the crop. As we get later in the season it gets drier and drier. Me and the sushi chef taste every single batch. It needs to have a specific firmness, and the release of starch also needs to be controlled so it's slightly sticky, meaning that I also vary the amount of rice conditioner and the time I spend rinsing it. The quality of the rice also varies along what proportion of the rice grains are broken; with higher proportions from lower quality crops(like the most recent Calrose crop) requiring additional rinsing as the broken grains release more starch,

>>18820882
Here you go:

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.


I THINK that the uneven flame/heat creates "heat turbulence" along with the specific shape of the pot. I haven't actually researched it all that much, so if anyone knows any better chime in please.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18825199
Look at instructions on bag of rice
do what it says for stovetop
rice comes out as expected

It's usually something like this:
1. add rice (you can prewash it but who gives a fuck you're making rice)
2. add equal amounts of water
3. turn on the heat until it starts boiling, uncovered (or boil the water before adding the rice who cares)
4. Once it boils turn the heat down to 1 for a simmer and cover it
5. wait 10 minutes
6. rice is done

If you care any further about how the rice tastes or looks go spend $10,000 on a dilator for your gaping front hole

The less water you use the firmer the rice stays up to the point where it won't be fully cooked. If you keep experimenting by only changing the alwater ratio you should find a firmness level you like.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
dal tadka over rice
3 servings
>cup dry lentils ($1)
>half an onion (80¢)
>quarter cup tomato (50¢)
>cup dry rice (10¢)
>optional: teaspoon or so of cilantro. (~20¢)
>optional: a curry leaf or two (basically free if bought in bulk)
>2 cloves garlic, equal amount of ginger (~10¢)
>spices (1 Bay leaf, 1 black cardamom, 2 green cardamom, 2 cloves, teaspoon cumin, teaspoon coriander, teaspoon cayenne, teaspoon turmeric, salt) (basically free if you buy in bulk)
>water (basically free)
soak lentils in water 30 minutes
mince garlic and ginger. chop onion fine. if using whole canned tomato, also chop fine.
get rice cookin'.
heat like a tablespoon of ghee or oil in a pan until it just starts to smoke, then take it off the heat. throw in the spices and the curry leaf. be sure to crack the cardamom pods (but don't crack them completely in half, cause you should pull out that black cardamom before eating). let it hang out in the hot oil for a minute or two. this is called "tempering" or "blooming," it generally makes spices taste stronger. common technique in Indian cooking.
throw in the garlic, ginger and onion, and salt. cook a few minutes, until you get a little browning. add lentils and 1½ to 2 cups of water. quick simmer for half an hour.
towards the end, add the tomato and the chopped cilantro. cook a few minutes more. pull out the bay leaf and black cardamom (and the green cardamom if you can find it, but don't worry too much about the green cardamom)
serve over rice

you got protein, veggies, vitamins and calories for like $1.40 a serving

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tuna casserole.
I didn't realize how poor I was growing up until I asked for this specific dish as my birthday meal. My cousin looked at me in disgust and her husband yelled out "That's a poor mans meal". I thought it was just something special my Grandpa made when I was a kid. Should have known since he always would talk about the food he ate during the depression.

Chicken and Rice with Cream of Mushroom Soup
This was a staple when I thought I could live off of a $7.25 an hour job on my own. Pretty sure I lived off of this meal for a week at a time.

Campbells mac and cheese
This is the absolute cheapest and horrid meal I have found on a recipe but it makes a lot. Campbells use to send out pamphlets with recipes for their canned soups for cheap dinners. This recipe calls for 1 can of condenses CHEDDAR CHEESE SOUP, milk and macaroni. Almost the same cost as a pack of Velveeta but makes a lot more and you'll always have extra noods.

>>18832500
Seconded. All you need to make real goulash is
>1 onion chopped
>2-3 cloves garlic
>1 tbsp paprika
>cheap stewing beef, cubed or sliced
>1/4 cup tomato paste
>salt and pepper to taste
>optional: 1 roasted and peeled red pepper, skin peeled off and chopped, cayenne or fresh hot pepper, a stock cube

>cook chopped onion in a bit of oil or butter in a heavy covered pot on medium heat for about 15 mins, stirring occasionally and adding water if it starts to stick to the pot
>cover the beef in the paprika and then remove the pot from heat, add the beef and start to brown the beef. return to heat and wait until your meat is fully browned.
>add tomato paste, garlic, salt and pepper and your optional ingredients and about a cup of water. Mix everything together, bring to a boil, and then simmer for up to 2 hours stirring occasionally.

the only thing that will truly convince you though is to cook good vegan food. but don't look up vegan recipes, you're just going to get garbage health food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18830612
For me, it's pate
>Sear then simmer with onions until soft (about 1h)
>Sautee mushrooms in separate pan
>Put liver+onion into blender
>Throw some other stuff into the blender for flavor (garlic cloves, black pepper, etc)
>Blend the mix
>Put it back into pan
>Chop up the mushrooms and put them in the pan (alternative - blend it with the mushrooms, depends if you want little pieces or blended)
>cook the mixture on low heat and uncovered to evaporate water
>taste it to add more seasoning or flavors (e.g., add salt, lemon)
>when the mix is fairly dry (soft but not watery), take off heat and let cool
>put into container and refrigerate
>enjoy on crackers, toast, etc

>>18823985
>Lustau sherry
Isn't that not even legally sherry in Europe? Like in the U.S. I think that's something like $12 a bottle, which for most people (not all) makes it just about drinkable, briefly, before you use it for cooking. The whiskeys are just all $25--35 range depending on where you shop, and are usually recommended as "introductory" or beginner affordable bottles. Also, there are several bartending guides which note that the required markup for using top-shelf liquors in cocktails is only a few cents per drink (coming to maybe a half to a dollar total altogether), which is a fixed cost where most of the markup for the cocktail is for labor, maintenance, and paying to keep the doors open -- so when you do the microeconomics correctly the customer should only pay that 50 cents extra per drink if you use top-shelf liquor, regardless of how cheap or expensive your bar is in general. In theory that's a price every customer would be happy to pay.

>>18824096
It's not that most of those liquors are *bad* for a consumer -- Banhez and Gran Centenario are considered very good bargain choices. Aside from the economics above, it's just that, to choose those liquors, the bar manager presumably would have had to see other liquors, and thus would know that these are some of the cheapest liquors out there (and would likely have had to do research to know that these are the cheapest ones that are actually drinkable, aside from the sherry). So then my biggest question is, **why advertise the brand names???** Hell, bars that use exclusively top-shelf liquors don't note the brand names, for many reasons.

The noob mistake I found out I was making earlier was using too old and too much citrus peel for the twists. They get more bitter with age, and given how big the twist was relative to how small the cocktails I'm making are, I think I'm just getting way too much bitterness from the peels. Also, after having this bitterness, not washing the glass instead of just rinsing is problematic. The one perfect Old Fashioned I made was with a cheap (but really good) blanco tequila and Peychauds in a fresh glass when I forgot to add another twist of my old citrus.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829178
If you followed the posts, I've only been practicing for like two months. And subtract a week with family plus a week stressing about it. Plus I'm only practicing every other day lately because I'm tired a lot and don't feel like drinking.

I grew up on wine. Learned a bit about tequila from a good liquor store and started really liking that. Went to a tasting class on fortified wines. But never thought about mixing until I went with a friend to a reasonably fancy bar (all bars are expensive in my area of the city) and had no idea what to order, so the bartender suggested an Old Fashioned. I was amazed by how good it was, and so (after the pandemic) I started looking for whiskey tastings and tried making OFs myself with the starter whiskey brand that was recommended (Four Roses, but I think if you're relatively experienced with wines and spirits in general just get a rye -- you don't need to be eased in with tacky sweet vanilla). I've been basing future purchases on reviews from a few reviewers who I seem to understand their attitude and what they're conveying in writing (for example, the main guy on DrinkHacker is explicit about not preferring reposado tequilas, which is a view I don't necessarily share, so I can adjust my evaluation of his reviews to my taste).

Finally, while I haven't been reading much in books, there's a cult favorite in the amateur internet that certainly has been really helpful for me getting started: "The 12 Bottle Bar" by Solmonson & Solmonson. I can't speak to their recipes, but they break down the basics in a really accessible way (I especially liked the bitters + vermouth as salt + pepper analogy).

M&R is perfectly acceptable to drink neat -- it's sweet and fruity and not complex, so it's a terrible neat vermouth, but it tastes fine -- sort of in the philosophy of a cheap-but-pleasantly-drinkable wine or whiskey. (I think the general consensus is to avoid M&R dry and that Noilly Prat is the next step up, with Cinzano and Boissiere also a good alternative on all varieties, and Dolin being the king of dry vermouth for mixing.

(Also side note on Noilly Prat that I came across: (via Alcademics 2013-08-04): USA “Extra-Dry” introduced 2013 is the same as USA “French Dry” 1979–2009. In 2009 USA “Original Dry” was the same as the international “Dry” version.)

Back tonight from mixing a tasting flight of 50mL gins (and a few OFs to sample new bitters, and some other sips) and just want to reiterate the ESSENTIALness of using fresh fruit for garnishes, aromatics, etc. Old citrus seems to be fine enough for juice I find, even if it's a bit dry and you're not getting much juice out (again, that may be a noob thing and I may be missing something fundamental there, but in other cooking and tasting myself the juice and the flesh on old citrus has always worked just as well).

Also, PSA for Americans: Aldi is (temporary afaik) selling jarred sour Morelo cherries in the for super cheap -- it's really tough to get sour cherries in the U.S. in any state other than super expensive imported ones specific to cocktails (thus with another markup for that), so this is really awesome. Downside is most of them look like shit, but more muddling and for home bar or practice garnishes -- and for any sour cherry usage in general -- it's more than adequate.

>>18826478
This is basically what I came here to say. If someone has taken the time to pay even minimal attention to how things in a kitchen are done "correctly", then they will very likely also care about how their food turns out. Over the course of a number of years, their dishes should casually turn out at least decent even when they aren't particularly trying.
People that don't know shit about cooking only have good meals when they get super lucky or they are relying entirely on the couple recipes they learned from a parent or friend that they do over and over and are fucked if something goes wrong during the preparation.
It's also why I appreciate women who are proud bakers, because while I'm not particularly crazy about baked good desserts, I know that it means they pay attention to what they're doing and have the patience to iterate. Successful and reliable baking requires a lot of tweaking of individual recipe components, and someone who doesn't care about cooking won't know where to start (or where to look to get started) on making adustments to a recipe that underperformed on the first pass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18826025
they understand temperature and how their pans react to their stovetop, they don't scorch oil and aren't afraid of a smoky kitchen, have good varieties of spice around their cooking area they clearly use frequently, and aren't afraid of using lots of fat in their cooking. Even if they use shitty store bought premade things a bit of care and technique can make a mediocre home chef produce food better than a mediocre linecook with ease

but the biggest tells are:
1.do they have a decent variety of meals they can cook that all cover major food groups and are well seasoned?
2. do they actually know how to cook the meat they're working with or just use it as a filler protein? (example: people who cook chicken thighs on the stove and wonder why they're chewy and unpleasant tasting, showing they don't know that the interconnective tissue needs to be cooked slowly first)
3. do they understand how to get a good sear? or, if they're using shitty glass stovetops and can't, do they know about using flour dredges and temperature management to get a good enough one?
4. do they own a dutch oven that they use? do they brown their slow cooked meat before letting it simmer, or are they one of those faggot morons that just lets massive chunks of fatty meat simmer in a crockpot making the kitchen smell awful
5. are they afraid of smoke in the kitchen? this is the biggest tell if someone isn't a good cook, if they panic when a nonstick pan starts to smoke then theyre not a good cook nor do they have any experience

>>18827852
>grind the salt yourself
Why would you do that? There's no aromatics sealed in the salt crystals that are released on grinding. It's fucking salt. Plus, by grinding them you'll get nonuniform grain sizes. The whole point of using (iodized or not, it doesn't matter) table salt (aka baking salt) is that the grains are roughly a consistent average size across manufacturers for a good century, making it usable by volume in baking recipes.

Kosher salt (or large-grained salt -- it literally doesn't matter whether it's kosher, iodized, or comes out of my asshole, as long as it's all salts of which 95+% or so are NaCl) is ubiquitous outside of baking because you can control it much more easily by hand, and it generally has a wider margin of error.

>>18830763
When people who /ck/ refer to "table salt" they mean the same thing as "baking salt", i.e. the fine-grained salt that comes in shakers and little salt packets at diners. Coarse-grained salts never fall under that definition. Just because your dinner table may use a coarse-grained salt does not make it useful or appropriate to refer to that with anyone outside your immediate family as "table salt".

It's like how my pre-dementia mother refers to every any new movie by the name of some famous vaguely similar one from 50 years ago. We all understand what we mean, but that doesn't mean that I should go around talking about "UHF" to movie buffs when I'm actually referring to film "Weird".

>>18829257
>>18829269
These are the right answers. No one is walking around with a compendium of cocktail recipes in their head. This isn't the 1950's.

Just figure out a simple cocktail that you like and stick with it everywhere you go. Don't ask for a mojito, don't ask for something gay and stupid like a singapore sling that has six ingredients. If the bartender has to touch three bottles for a cocktail, they will hate you. Don't ask for anything with red bull. Don't ask for long island iced tea unless you're in a club setting (if you don't know the difference between a club, a pub, a bar, a cocktail lounge, etc, then don't ask for a long island iced tea).

If it's a reasonably okay bar, just ask for a rum daiquiri if you want something refreshing and light. It's delicious. Rum, lime, sugar syrup, shaken hard and served ice cold. If you want something boozier and more.. "manly", ask for a Manhattan or an old fashioned. If you want something manageable that you can sip on for a while, get a highball, which is spirit + carbonated liquid: vodka soda, gin and tonic, tequila soda, whiskey soda. You can just ask for a Jameson highball and the bartender will know what you mean.

You can always ask for a whiskey on the rocks or neat and the bartender will totally respect you for it, especially if it's a nice whiskey. You'll need to specify by brand. Doesn't ask for "whiskey on the rocks", that's what fucking alcoholics and retards ask for.

Don't ask for doubles. Don't ask a bartender to "make it strong". Just order a drink like a real, normal human being who isn't a total retard and is visiting earth for the first time ever.

My usual drink order is a Victoria (mexican beer) and a fernet (italian amaro, very bitter, very unique). A boilermaker or "shot and a beer" is a common combo that will put your bartender at ease.

>>18830658
1)Add oil to pan/pot
2)Heat pan/pot on medium heat
3)Add meat when it's hot enough
4)Break it up into a uniform mass with a wooden spoon, season to taste
5)Stir it up for around 10 minutes
6)Add tomato paste/smashed tomatoes
7)Wait until it bubbles
8)Lower heat as low as it goes
9)Leave it to thicken up 2-3 hours or as long as you please

That's the basic stuff. If you want to get anal about it you can slip in a quick 3-5 minute saute of onions, garlic, carrots, etc. between steps 2 and 3.

Experiment with cooking times, ingredients and add/decrease steps as you please, I'm not an expert.
